items.content: Hurrah! Poetry and passion, comedy and tragedy are fused into one absolutely marvelous affirmation of independent spirit in Dead Poets Society. [2 June 1989, Daily Notebook, p.E1]
One of Australian director Peter Weir's most sensitive films.

items.author: Pauline Kael
items.content: The picture draws out the obvious and turns itself into a classic. [26 June 1989]

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: Sure, the heroes and villains are arranged in a convenient moral gallery. But the performances, Weir's adroit direction and John Seale's superb cinematography take care of that banality.

items.author: Stanley Kauffmann
items.content: Nothing about this film sounds, as described, novel. Yet it grips, because it has been made with plentiful feeling and vigor. [June 26, 1989]

items.author: Michael Wilmington
items.content: Commands respect and affection. [2 June 1989, Calendar, p.6-1]

items.author: Mike Clark
items.content: Williams is impressively restrained as well as funny, so fans need not fret. It only means that instead of Good Morning, Preppies, we're given a bittersweet, even eerie Goodbye, Mr. Hip. [2 June 1989, Life, p.1D]

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: Williams, who has comparatively little screen time, has come to act, not to cut comic riffs, and he does so with forceful, ultimately compelling, simplicity. [June 5, 1989]

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Not the worst of the countless recent movies about good kids and hidebound, authoritatian older people. It may, however, be the most shameless in its attempt to pander to an adolescent audience.
